ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Course consisted of two weekly live zoom meetings where we learned the mechanics of Adobe creative cloud programs, and looked at the work of other famous photographers. Some classes were structured as working sessions, where students could be focusing on their own work and ask questions to Professor Partin and Alex, the TA.
Sitting in on artist talks.
Live over zoom two sessions a week, with a few days dedicated to working sessions or time to photograph.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the mechanics of how a DSLR actually works, how to manipulate features on the camera depending on the lighting you're working with, safety measures when it comes to taking care of a camera, working with Adobe Bridge, Camera Raw, Photoshop, and more from the Adobe Creative Cloud. I learned quite a bit and Ted is a great teacher.
The basics of how to use a digital camera, Photoshop, Lightroom, and Adobe Camera Raw! Great well-rounded course.
I learned the basics of using a dSLR, camera raw, and photoshop. I was also challenged to go out of my photography comfort zone which was great!
I learned how to use a DSLR and a lot beyond just the technical aspects of making a photo.
A great introductory class that focuses on LEARNING and not GRADES.
I learned basic photography skills and the process behind making a photo book.

I learned how to use my DSLR more than just recreationally. I became familiar with basic settings and basic editing on Photoshop as well. I also gained valuable insight about photography as an art form by looking at different photographers' work and figuring out my own style.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The course is so very flexibly and really does allow for students to take their own creative approach to things. Ted is not strict with how things should be presented or how class should be run, so a lot of the time we would use class time however we saw fit, whether that was answering logistical questions that people had about the software we were using, or looking at other's work for inspiration, and literally using class time to go out and photograph. 

That being said, this class really is what you make of it. This semester in particular, there were no formal check ins to hold you accountable for taking a certain number of pictures per week, so practicing your skills was really an active choice that you had to hold yourself to make.
Strengths: very hands-off for COVID-era. Ted was a phenomenal professor who was flexible and knowledgeable about all things photography. Be prepared with questions to get the most of out the class.

The professor and TA were really helpful and encouraging. I wish there was more content in the class, though. For instance, it would have been nice to learn more of the technical aspects of photography.
Great class with lots of great advice given throughout the semester.
It was a great course to have during quarantine, esp. because it encouraged solo exploration/deeper thought about how we interact with our surroundings.

Strengths: I enjoyed the creative freedom we had over our work, it really made me much more observant and aware of the little things around me. I also appreciated the critiques we had. The were chances to show what we were working on and hear from others what was working and what could be improved.

Weaknesses: This is not really a weakness of the course itself, but the online/remote format was disappointing. I really enjoyed the course and I wish I had waited to take it in all its glory in-person.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The flexibility in the class and the material of the class itself was absolutely a gift during the COVID-pandemic. This class added no extra stress onto the semester, but allowed me to have a creative outlet that I had to make time for, which was necessary in my opinion during this year.
I think this class was adapted as well as it could be for being virtual.
This class was great online. Small class and the ability to share pictures from all over.

This being a photography course, the everyone used their different settings in their artwork made for very interesting and different works to look at. 
Even though we could not get feedback in person, I think the way critiques and working sessions were structured worked well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Ted is a wonderful teacher who will both challenge you to improve your photography skills, and be supportive of your progress and learning, as fast or as slow as they may be. This is one of the few classes that I have taken at Yale where I am actually excited to go to and be in class. Sharing my own work has been so enjoyable, and looking at other's work for inspiration has also been another exciting aspect about the class. Take this class if you enjoy capturing pictures, but also be aware that anything you gain from this class will be directly related to how much time and effort and practice you put into the class material itself.
Absolutely! if you're at all interested in the basics of digital photography, and how to take some aesthetic pics, and how to use Photoshop, this is a great intro course.
Yes! It is a lot of fun!
YES. This class was my first art class at Yale and it was an absolute gem. It was a really nice change up from my quantitative STEM classes.
Absolutely! I wish I had taken this class sooner. Ted is a wonderful professor. You get out of the class what you put in and if you want to learn photography this is the way to do it.
Definitely.

I would recommend this course to beginners looking to expand their basic skills and knowledge of photography. It learned to take my camera wherever I go and pay attention to things I wouldn't have noticed before this course.
